Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2012 01:46PM iswimibikeirun wrote: Scaredycat--for me, the worst part was waiting for my appointment.  They told me the wrong time.  As for the procedure itself, the initial numbing was the worst.  Within 2 hours after they took me to have the procedure done, I was back in my office working.  Personally, I think having my teeth cleaned is worse!
Posts.Title: steroetactic biopsy scaredycatwoman geebung

Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 09:16AM iswimibikeirun wrote: Hehe.  One of mine fell out on its own, so I didn't feel that.  I don't think I really noticed the other being removed until after the fact.  It wasn't as bad as I thought (or imagined).  I think I was distracted because they were removing sutures at the same time and I could feel that.
Posts.Title: Drain removal with no pain meds?! Stormynyte SerendipiTea

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2012 02:10PM iswimibikeirun wrote: The initial numbing shot was a loud noise--much like what you get when you get a tooth filled/drilled.  I guess it was mostly the prick of the needle.  I don't like needles very much and the good thing was I couldn't see it.  My technician/assistant was very calming--she stroked my back during some of the procedure.  Honestly, I didn't think the procedure was that bad. What I wasn't prepared for was the fact that they wrapped me in a huge bandage and I was wearing a v-neck sweater.  I didn't want to have to explain myself all day--the bandage was visible from the v-neck.  My only instructions after were to keep the bandage on for 24 hours and not pick at the steri strips.  I ony had a small bruise at the site after and I didn't even notice it unless I looked in the mirror.  The sound of the the vacuum assisted device was more intimidating, but it was just a noise.  Honestly, the 2 hours I was there included my waiting time and the time it took to fill out paperwork, do the test, have a marker put in, and everything.  I personally never felt punched in the chest (although it sounded like it).  I guess another interesting thing was that the radiologist who did the procedure is known for having his ipod playing with calming music during the procedure.  You might consider bringing your ipod.
